headline: America's Political Future (Still) Hinges on Georgia
author: Margaret Newkirk
sentences:
Duncan says Perdue's run is a mistake: There is no math that makes it easier to beat Stacey Abrams by having David Perdue in the race.?
Georgiaonce a bastion of racial segregation but now a powerhouse of Black business and politicswill also test whether Democrats can overcome Republican moves to limit voting to tilt elections in their favor.

On the ballot: Stacey Abrams, the organizing powerhouse credited with turning Georgia blue in 2020 and a national lightning rod for Republican rage; Kemp, the sitting GOP governor who beat her in 2018; and David Perdue, who lost his seat in the Senate to then-33-year-old Jon Ossoff in January 2021 and is now challenging Kemp in the primary.

Republican consultant Brian Robinson says Perdue's pitch is that a significant minority of Republicans have lost faith in Kemp and will not show up to vote,? which would tip the race to Abrams.

Stung by 2020's losses, exurban and suburban Republicans changed governmental structures, clamped down on measures meant to make voting easier, and drew new congressional boundaries to dilute the growing Democratic majority in Atlanta's outskirts.

Not only did Georgians choose a Democrat for president for the first time in decades, helping Joe Biden clinch a victory, but they also elected two Democrats to the U.S. Senate in January 2021, giving the party razor-thin control of that chamber.

Kemp's counterargument, in Robinson's words: I'm the only person in the race who has ever beat Abrams, and you [Perdue] couldn't even beat Jon Ossoff.?
Nor is Kemp the only Georgia Republican suffering the wrath of Trump and his supporters.

His backers are trying to defeat Secretary of State Brad Raffensperger, the top elections official, who debunked Trump's voter-fraud claims and refused to overturn the 2020 results.
With Republican Governor Brian Kemp delivering his state of the state address Jan. 13 and unofficially kicking off his fight for reelection, the spotlight is about to return.
After becoming the first Black senator in Georgia historywinning only a partial term in office in a special electionRaphael Warnock will vie for a full term in November.
It also remains to be seen how loyal the state's most active Democrats remain if Biden and Congress don't deliver on federal voting rights legislation.
